unnormalised: ## Lights, Camera, Festival! Why Film Festivals are More Than Just Fancy Parties
normalised: ## Lights, Camera, Festival! Why Film Festivals are More Than Just Fancy Parties

unnormalised: Hey everyone! So, you know how much we Desis love a good celebration, right? Well, film festivals are kinda like that, but with movies instead of ladoos (though sometimes there *are* ladoos, depending on which festival you're at!). But seriously, they're way more than just glamorous events where Bollywood celebs strut their stuff in designer clothes.

unnormalised: Think of a film festival as a melting pot – a place where indie filmmakers from Kerala rub shoulders with seasoned directors from Yash Raj Films, and where international critics debate the merits of a Marathi arthouse film. It's a chance to discover hidden gems you’d probably never see on Netflix.

unnormalised: I remember attending the Kolkata International Film Festival last year. It was insane! Saw some incredible documentaries, short films that blew my mind, and even got to attend a Q&A with a director whose work I've admired for ages. The energy was electric!
normalised: I remember attending the Kolkata International Film Festival last year. It was insane! Saw some incredible documentaries, short films that blew my mind, and even got to attend a Q and A with a director whose work I've admired for ages. The energy was electric!

unnormalised: But film festivals aren't just for cinephiles. They’re also a huge boost for the local economy. Think of all the hotels booked, restaurants buzzing, and transport providers getting a piece of the pie. Plus, they often offer workshops and masterclasses for aspiring filmmakers, providing invaluable learning opportunities. The International Film Festival of India (IFFI) in Goa, for instance, is a massive draw, bringing in filmmakers from all over the world and showcasing the best of Indian cinema. It's a whole week of movie madness!

unnormalised: From the Jaipur International Film Festival showcasing Rajasthani culture to smaller, more niche festivals focusing on specific genres, there’s a film festival out there for everyone. So, next time you see one advertised, don't just think of it as a celebrity-filled party. Think of it as a chance to discover new stories, support independent cinema, and maybe even spot your favorite Bollywood star grabbing a samosa. What's not to love?
